SECRET CP. 528(24)CABINS T.Home Affairs Committee.Importation of Pedigree Animals Bill'-Memorandum by the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries.The accompanying Bill is required to implement the undertaking given to the Imperial Economic Conference, 1923, to facilitate Inter-v-Imperial trade in pedigree stock throughout the Empire on reciprocal terms. Though on the whole averse to any importation of breeding stock into this country, agricultural interests, who were consulted at the time of the Conference, agreed that subject to proper safeguards, the import of pedigree stock might be allowed.Under Section 27 of the Diseases of Animals Act, 1394, the Minister has power to make an Ordar "for allowing the landing of any foreign animals intended for exhibition or for other exceptional purposes". Since the passing of the Act of 1894 this Section has been c on3trued very strictly, and this power has been only exorcised to allow importations of pedigree stock on very few occasions. It is proposed in the Bill to extend the limited power of tho Minister under Section 27 so as to cover the importation from the Dominions of registered pedigree stock for any purposes, although naturally breeding is the purpose for which they would generally be imported. Animals imported under the Bill will not be subject to part I of the Third Schedule of the Act of -1894, which requires slaughter on landing, but will be subjectCopy No. to quarantine as required by Part 2 of that Schedule. The period of quarantine will be entirely within ray discretion and It will be prescribed by the Landing Order.The intention is to make Orders allowing the landing of particular animals, and not to issue a general Order allowing e.g., the landing in Great Britain of any cattle brought from Canada which are registered in a recognised Canadian herd book.The necessity for sub-section (3) is that Section 5 of the Act of 1932 refers only to animals in an "imported animals wharf" or "approved landing place", both of which expressions have a technical meaning and might not be held to include an "imported animals quarantine station", such as would be provided for animals landed under the new Act.Sub-Section (4) Is required, as the Schedule applies generally to imported animals with the exception only of animals landed "for exhibition or other exceptional purposes".During the past few months the South African Government have been pressing very hard for Section 27 of the Act of 1894 to be strained in order to allow the import of a consignment of pedigree ?riesian cattle from South Africa, and this request has been resisted on the ground that the issue of an Order by the Ministry for such a purpose would clearly be contrary to the spirit of Section 27 and could not be justified in Parliament, especially when a Bill to authorise such importations was already in draft. I hope, therefore, that I may be authorised to introduce the Bill' at an early date, and to proceed with it as soon after the Christmas Adjournment as opportunity offers.Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, 8th December 1924. (1) Subject to the provisions of this section the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries (hereinafter referred to as the Minister) may make orders for allowing, subject to such conditions as may be prescribed by any such10 order, any cattle, sheep, goats or swine brought from any part of His Majesty's dominions, which are shown to his satisfaction to be there registered as pedigree stock in a herd or flock book recognised by him, to be landed in Great Britain without being subject to the provisions of15 Part I. of the Third Schedule to the Diseases of Animals Act, 1894 (which relate to slaughter at the port of landing), but subject to the provisions of Part II. of that Schedule (which relate to quarantine):Provided that no such order shall be made except with20 respect to animals brought from a part of His Majesty's dominions in which pedigree animals brought from Great Britain are allowed to be landed either uncondi-tionally or subject to conditions (including rates of import duties) which in the opinion of the Minister are25 not unduly restrictive. 34-1 WPower of Minister to allow im-portation of pedigree animals. Importation of Pedigree [15 Geo. 5.] Animals.A.D. 1924.Interpreta-tion and extent.Short title.(2) Paragraph (&) of section twenty-four of the Diseases of Animals Act, 1894, as amended by any subsequent enactment, shall apply to any animals allowed to be landed under this Act as it applies to animals the landing of which is allowed under that Act.(3) Section five of the Importation of Animals Act, 1922 (Session 2) (which provides that compensation shall not be payable in respect of the slaughter of imported animals in certain cases), shall apply in respect of any imported animal which having been allowed to be landed under this Act is slaughtered in a quarantine station by reason of the animal being diseased, or suspected of having been exposed to the infection of any disease.(4) Notwithstanding anything in the Importation of Animals Act, 1922 (Session 2), the provisions contained in the Schedule to that Act (which relate to the regula-tion of movement of imported cattle) shall not apply to any animals allowed to be landed under this Act except in so far as they may be applied with or without modifications by the order allowing the animals to be landed.2. For the purposes of this Act the expression " His Majesty's dominions " includes any territory which is under His Majesty's protection or in respect of which a mandate is being exercised by the Government of any 25 part of His Majesty's dominions.3. This Act may be cited as the Importation of Pedigree Animals Act, 1925, and the Diseases of Animals Acts, 1894 to 1922, and this Act may be cited together as the Diseases of Animals Acts, 1894 to 1925. 30101520
